<h3 id="1.2-KMeans-Implementation-[30pts]">1.2 KMeans Implementation</h3>

In this section, you are asked to implement _init_centers [5pts], _update_assignment [10pts], _update_centers [10pts] and _get_loss function [5pts].

For the function signature, please see the corresponding doc strings.

<h3 id="1.3-Find-the-optimal-number-of-clusters-[10-pts]">1.3 Find the optimal number of clusters</h3>

In this section, you are asked to implement find_optimal_num_clusters function.

You will now use the elbow method to find the optimal number of clusters.

<h3 id="1.4-Autograder-test-to-find-centers-for-data-points-[5-pts]">1.4 Autograder test to find centers for data points</h3>

To obtain these 5 points, you need to be pass the tests set up in the autograder. These will test the centers created by your implementation. Be sure to upload the correct files to obtain these points.

In [2]:

<pre><span class="k">class</span> <span class="nc">KMeans</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">object</span><span class="p">):</span>        <span class="k">def</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="p">):</span> <span class="c1"># [5 pts]</span>        <span class="sd">"""</span><span class="sd">        Args:</span><span class="sd">            x: N x D numpy array</span><span class="sd">            y: M x D numpy array</span><span class="sd">        Return:</span><span class="sd">                dist: N x M array, where dist2[i, j] is the euclidean distance between </span><span class="sd">                x[i, :] and y[j, :]</span><span class="sd">                """</span>        <span class="c1">#l2 norm, ord=2</span>        <span class="n">dist</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linalg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">norm</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="p">[:,</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">newaxis</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="p">:]</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">ord</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">axis</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>        <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">dist</span><span class="c1">#         raise NotImplementedError</span>    <span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">_init_centers</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">points</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">K</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="o">**</span><span class="n">kwargs</span><span class="p">):</span> <span class="c1"># [5 pts]</span>        <span class="sd">"""</span><span class="sd">        Args:</span><span class="sd">            points: NxD numpy array, where N is # points and D is the dimensionality</span><span class="sd">            K: number of clusters</span><span class="sd">            kwargs: any additional arguments you want</span><span class="sd">        Return:</span><span class="sd">            centers: K x D numpy array, the centers. </span><span class="sd">        """</span>        <span class="c1">#K random indices from points</span>        <span class="n">indices</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">choice</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">points</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">shape</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">size</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">K</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">replace</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">False</span><span class="p">)</span>        <span class="c1">#form the numpy array with these indices</span>        <span class="n">centers</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">points</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">indices</span><span class="p">,:]</span>        <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">centers</span>        <span class="c1">#         raise NotImplementedError</span>    <span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">_update_assignment</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">centers</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">points</span><span class="p">):</span> <span class="c1"># [10 pts]</span>        <span class="sd">"""</span><span class="sd">        Args:</span><span class="sd">            centers: KxD numpy array, where K is the number of clusters, and D is the dimension</span><span class="sd">            points: NxD numpy array, the observations</span><span class="sd">        Return:</span><span class="sd">            cluster_idx: numpy array of length N, the cluster assignment for each point</span>            <span class="sd">        Hint: You could call pairwise_dist() function.</span><span class="sd">        """</span>        <span class="c1">#distances between points and all cluster centers</span>        <span class="n">distances</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pairwise_dist</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">points</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">centers</span><span class="p">)</span>        <span class="c1">#index of minimum distance for each row</span>        <span class="n">cluster_idx</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">argmin</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">distances</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">axis</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span>        <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">cluster_idx</span><span class="c1">#         raise NotImplementedError</span>    <span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">_update_centers</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">old_centers</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cluster_idx</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">points</span><span class="p">):</span> <span class="c1"># [10 pts]</span>        <span class="sd">"""</span><span class="sd">        Args:</span><span class="sd">            old_centers: old centers KxD numpy array, where K is the number of clusters, and D is the dimension</span><span class="sd">            cluster_idx: numpy array of length N, the cluster assignment for each point</span><span class="sd">            points: NxD numpy array, the observations</span><span class="sd">        Return:</span><span class="sd">            centers: new centers, K x D numpy array, where K is the number of clusters, and D is the dimension.</span><span class="sd">        """</span>        <span class="n">K</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">D</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">old_centers</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">shape</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">old_centers</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">shape</span><span class="p">[</span><span <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">i</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="nb">range</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">K</span><span class="p">):</span>            <span class="c1">#find mean of all points having i as cluster idx</span>            <span class="n">centers</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">_get_loss</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">centers</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cluster_idx</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">points</span><span class="p">):</span> <span class="c1"># [5 pts]</span>        <span class="sd">"""</span><span class="sd"> the cluster assignment for each point</span><span class="sd">            points: NxD numpy array, the observations</span><span class="sd">        Return:</span><span class="sd">            loss: a single float number, which is the objective function of KMeans. </span><span class="sd">        """</span>        <span class="c1">#find squared distances between all points and cluster centers</span>        <span class="n">distances</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linalg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">norm</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">points</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">K</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">max_iters</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">abs_tol</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">1e-16</span><span Args:</span><span class="sd">            points: NxD numpy array, where N is # points and D is the dimensionality</span><span class="sd">            K: number of clusters</span><span class="sd">            max_iters: maximum number of iterations (Hint: You could change it when debugging)</span><span class="sd">            abs_tol: convergence criteria w.r.t absolute change of loss</span><span class="sd">            rel_tol: convergence criteria w.r.t relative change of loss</span><span class="sd">            verbose: boolean to set whether method should print loss (Hint: helpful for       <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">it</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="nb">range</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">max_iters</span><span class="p">):</span>            <span class="n">cluster_idx</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="bp">self</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_update_assignment</span><span class="p">(</span><span <span class="n">diff</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">abs</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">prev_loss</span> <span <span class="ow">and</span> <span class="n">diff</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="n">prev_loss</span> <span class="o">&lt;</span> <span class="n">rel_tol</span><span class="p">:</span>                    <span class="k">break</span>            <span class="n">prev_loss</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">loss</span>            <span class="k">if</span> <span </span><span class="si">%.4f</span><span class="s1">'</span> <span class="o">%</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">it</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">loss</span><span   """</span>        <span class="n">losses</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[]</span>        <span class="c1">#for each value of K, find the loss and append to array</span>        <span <pre><span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">image_to_matrix</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">image_file</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">grays</span><span (color) np.ndarray[np.ndarray[np.ndarray[float]]]</span><span class="sd">    or (grayscale) np.ndarray[np.ndarray[float]]</span><span class="sd">    """</span>    <span class="n">img</span> <span <h2 id="Silhouette-Coefficient-Evaluation-[10-pts]">Silhouette Coefficient Evaluation</h2>

The average silhouette of the data is another useful criterion for assessing the natural number of clusters. The silhouette of a data instance is a measure of how closely it is matched to data within its cluster and how loosely it is matched to data of the neighbouring cluster.

The silhouette value is a measure of how similar an object is to its own cluster (cohesion) compared to other clusters (separation). The silhouette ranges from −1 to +1, where a high value indicates that the object is well matched to its own cluster and poorly matched to neighboring clusters. If most objects have a high value, then the clustering configuration is appropriate. If many points have a low or negative value, then the clustering configuration may have too many or too few clusters.

In [7]:

<span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">rand</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">200</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="mi">100</span><span class="n">plot_silhouette_coefficient</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">)</span></pre>

Out[8]:

<h3 id="Limitation-of-K-Means">Limitation of K-Means</h3>

One of the limitations of K-Means Clustering is that it dependes largely on the shape of the dataset. A common example of this is trying to cluster one circle within another (concentric circles). A K-means classifier will fail to do this and will end up effectively drawing a line which crosses the circles. You can visualize this limitation in the cell below.

In [9]:

<pre><span class="c1"># visualize limitation of kmeans, do not have to implement</span><span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">sklearn.datasets.samples_generator</span> <span class="k">import</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">make_circles</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">make_moons</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="n">X1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">make_circles</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">factor</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.5</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">noise</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.05</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">n_samples</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">1500</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="n">X2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y2</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">make_moons</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">noise</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.05</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">n_samples</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">1500</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">visualise</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">C</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">K</span><span class="p">):</span><span class="c1"># Visualization of clustering. <h2 id="2.-EM-algorithm-[20-pts]">2. EM algorithm [20 pts]</h2>

<h3 id="2.1-Performing-EM-Update-[10-pts]">2.1 Performing EM Update [10 pts]</h3>

A univariate Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM) has two components, both of which have their own mean and standard deviation. The model is defined by the following parameters:

For a dataset of N datapoints, find the following:

2.1.1. Write the marginal probability of x, i.e. <span id="MathJax-Element-12-Frame" class="MathJax" style="box-sizing: border-box; display: inline-table; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: normal; font-size: 14px; text-indent: 0px; text-align: left; text-transform: none; letter-spacing: normal; word-spacing: normal; overflow-wrap: normal; white-space: nowrap; float: none; direction: ltr; max-width: none; max-height: none; min-width: 0px; min-height: 0px; border: 0px; padding: 0px; margin: 0px; position: relative;" tabindex="0" role="presentation" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow class=&quot;MJX-TeXAtom-ORD&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;bold&quot;>p</mi><mo mathvariant=&quot;bold&quot; stretchy=&quot;false&quot;>(</mo><mi mathvariant=&quot;bold&quot;>x</mi><mo mathvariant=&quot;bold&quot; stretchy=&quot;false&quot;>)</mo></mrow></math>"><span id="MathJax-Span-248" class="math"><span id="MathJax-Span-249" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-250" class="texatom"><span id="MathJax-Span-251" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-252" class="mi">p</span><span id="MathJax-Span-253" class="mo">(</span><span id="MathJax-Span-254" class="mi">x</span><span id="MathJax-Span-255" class="mo">)</span></span></span></span></span><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation">p(x)</span></span> [2pts]

2.1.2. E-Step: Compute the posterior probability, i.e, <span id="MathJax-Element-13-Frame" class="MathJax" style="box-sizing: border-box; display: inline-table; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: normal; font-size: 14px; text-indent: 0px; text-align: left; text-transform: none; letter-spacing: normal; word-spacing: normal; overflow-wrap: normal; white-space: nowrap; float: none; direction: ltr; max-width: none; max-height: none; min-width: 0px; min-height: 0px; border: 0px; padding: 0px; margin: 0px; position: relative;" tabindex="0" role="presentation" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mi>p</mi><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot;>(</mo><msup><mi>z</mi><mi>i</mi></msup><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi><mrow class=&quot;MJX-TeXAtom-ORD&quot;><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot;>|</mo></mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msup><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot;>)</mo></math>"><span id="MathJax-Span-256" class="math"><span id="MathJax-Span-257" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-258" class="mi">p</span><span id="MathJax-Span-259" class="mo">(</span><span id="MathJax-Span-260" class="msubsup"><span id="MathJax-Span-261" class="mi">z</span><span id="MathJax-Span-262" class="mi">i</span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-263" class="mo">=</span><span id="MathJax-Span-264" class="mi">k</span><span id="MathJax-Span-265" class="texatom"><span id="MathJax-Span-266" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-267" class="mo">|</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-268" class="msubsup"><span id="MathJax-Span-269" class="mi">x</span><span id="MathJax-Span-270" class="mi">i</span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-271" class="mo">)</span></span></span><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation">p(zi=k|xi)</span></span>, where k = {0,1} [2pts]

2.1.3. M-Step: Compute the updated value of <span id="MathJax-Element-14-Frame" class="MathJax" style="box-sizing: border-box; display: inline-table; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: normal; font-size: 14px; text-indent: 0px; text-align: left; text-transform: none; letter-spacing: normal; word-spacing: normal; overflow-wrap: normal; white-space: nowrap; float: none; direction: ltr; max-width: none; max-height: none; min-width: 0px; min-height: 0px; border: 0px; padding: 0px; margin: 0px; position: relative;" tabindex="0" role="presentation" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mi>&amp;#x03BC;</mi></math>"><span id="MathJax-Span-272" class="math"><span id="MathJax-Span-273" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-274" class="mi">μ</span></span></span><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation">μ</span></span> (You can keep <span id="MathJax-Element-15-Frame" class="MathJax" style="box-sizing: border-box; display: inline-table; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: normal; font-size: 14px; text-indent: 0px; text-align: left; text-transform: none; letter-spacing: normal; word-spacing: normal; overflow-wrap: normal; white-space: nowrap; float: none; direction: ltr; max-width: none; max-height: none; min-width: 0px; min-height: 0px; border: 0px; padding: 0px; margin: 0px; position: relative;" tabindex="0" role="presentation" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mi>&amp;#x03C3;</mi></math>"><span id="MathJax-Span-275" class="math"><span id="MathJax-Span-276" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-277" class="mi">σ</span></span></span><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation">σ</span></span> fixed for this) [3pts]

2.1.4. M-Step: Compute the updated value for <span id="MathJax-Element-16-Frame" class="MathJax" style="box-sizing: border-box; display: inline-table; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: normal; font-size: 14px; text-indent: 0px; text-align: left; text-transform: none; letter-spacing: normal; word-spacing: normal; overflow-wrap: normal; white-space: nowrap; float: none; direction: ltr; max-width: none; max-height: none; min-width: 0px; min-height: 0px; border: 0px; padding: 0px; margin: 0px; position: relative;" tabindex="0" role="presentation" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mi>&amp;#x03C3;</mi></math>"><span id="MathJax-Span-278" class="math"><span id="MathJax-Span-279" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-280" class="mi">σ</span></span></span><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation">σ</span></span> (You can keep <span id="MathJax-Element-17-Frame" class="MathJax" style="box-sizing: border-box; display: inline-table; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: normal; font-size: 14px; text-indent: 0px; text-align: left; text-transform: none; letter-spacing: normal; word-spacing: normal; overflow-wrap: normal; white-space: nowrap; float: none; direction: ltr; max-width: none; max-height: none; min-width: 0px; min-height: 0px; border: 0px; padding: 0px; margin: 0px; position: relative;" tabindex="0" role="presentation" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mi>&amp;#x03BC;</mi></math>"><span id="MathJax-Span-281" class="math"><span id="MathJax-Span-282" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-283" class="mi">μ</span></span></span><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation">μ</span></span> fixed for this) [3pts]

<span id="MathJax-Element-9-Frame" class="MathJax" style="box-sizing: border-box; display: inline-table; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: normal; font-size: 14px; text-indent: 0px; text-align: center; text-transform: none; letter-spacing: normal; word-spacing: normal; overflow-wrap: normal; white-space: nowrap; float: none; direction: ltr; max-width: none; max-height: none; min-width: 0px; min-height: 0px; border: 0px; padding: 0px; margin: 0px; position: relative;" tabindex="0" role="presentation" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot; display=&quot;block&quot;><mrow class=&quot;MJX-TeXAtom-ORD&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;bold&quot;>z</mi></mrow><mo>&amp;#x223C;</mo><mi>B</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>u</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot;>(</mo><mi>&amp;#x03B8;</mi><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot;>)</mo></math>"><span id="MathJax-Span-182" class="math"><span id="MathJax-Span-183" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-184" class="texatom"><span id="MathJax-Span-185" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-186" class="mi">z</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-187" class="mo">∼</span><span id="MathJax-Span-188" class="mi">B</span><span id="MathJax-Span-189" class="mi">e</span><span id="MathJax-Span-190" class="mi">r</span><span id="MathJax-Span-191" class="mi">n</span><span id="MathJax-Span-192" class="mi">o</span><span id="MathJax-Span-193" class="mi">u</span><span id="MathJax-Span-194" class="mi">l</span><span id="MathJax-Span-195" class="mi">l</span><span id="MathJax-Span-196" class="mi">i</span><span id="MathJax-Span-197" class="mo">(</span><span id="MathJax-Span-198" class="mi">θ</span><span id="MathJax-Span-199" class="mo">)</span></span></span><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML MJX_Assistive_MathML_Block" role="presentation">z∼Bernoulli(θ)</span></span>

<span id="MathJax-Element-10-Frame" class="MathJax" style="box-sizing: border-box; display: inline-table; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: normal; font-size: 14px; text-indent: 0px; 2.1.1 Marginal probability of x, i.e. <span id="MathJax-Element-18-Frame" class="MathJax" style="box-sizing: border-box; display: inline-table; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: normal; font-size: 14px; text-indent: 0px; text-align: left; text-transform: none; letter-spacing: normal; word-spacing: normal; overflow-wrap: normal; white-space: nowrap; float: none; direction: ltr; max-width: none; max-height: none; min-width: 0px; min-height: 0px; border: 0px; padding: 0px; margin: 0px; position: relative;" tabindex="0" role="presentation" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow class=&quot;MJX-TeXAtom-ORD&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;bold&quot;>p</mi><mo mathvariant=&quot;bold&quot; stretchy=&quot;false&quot;>(</mo><mi mathvariant=&quot;bold&quot;>x</mi><mo mathvariant=&quot;bold&quot; stretchy=&quot;false&quot;>)</mo></mrow></math>"><span id="MathJax-Span-284" class="math"><span id="MathJax-Span-285" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-286" class="texatom"><span id="MathJax-Span-287" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-288" class="mi">p</span><span id="MathJax-Span-289" class="mo">(</span><span id="MathJax-Span-290" class="mi">x</span><span id="MathJax-Span-291" class="mo">)</span></span></span></span></span><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation">p(x)</span></span>Given: A univariate Gaussian mixture model with two components, defined by their parameters as:

Note: Considering <span id="MathJax-Element-22-Frame" class="MathJax" style="box-sizing: border-box; display: inline-table; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: normal; font-size: 14px; Marginal probability of x can be calculated as:

2.1.2 E-Step: Posterior probability, i.e, <span id="MathJax-Element-26-Frame" class="MathJax" style="box-sizing: border-box; display: inline-table; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: normal; font-size: 14px; text-indent: 0px; text-align: left; text-transform: none; letter-spacing: normal; word-spacing: normal; overflow-wrap: normal; white-space: nowrap; float: none; direction: ltr; max-width: none; max-height: none; min-width: 0px; min-height: 0px; border: 0px; padding: 0px; margin: 0px; position: relative;" tabindex="0" role="presentation" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mi>p</mi><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot;>(</mo><msup><mi>z</mi><mi>i</mi></msup><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi><mrow class=&quot;MJX-TeXAtom-ORD&quot;><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot;>|</mo></mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mi>i</mi></msup><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot;>)</mo></math>"><span id="MathJax-Span-478" class="math"><span id="MathJax-Span-479" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-480" class="mi">p</span><span id="MathJax-Span-481" class="mo">(</span><span id="MathJax-Span-482" class="msubsup"><span id="MathJax-Span-483" class="mi">z</span><span id="MathJax-Span-484" class="mi">i</span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-485" class="mo">=</span><span id="MathJax-Span-486" class="mi">k</span><span id="MathJax-Span-487" class="texatom"><span id="MathJax-Span-488" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-489" class="mo">|</span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-490" class="msubsup"><span id="MathJax-Span-491" class="mi">x</span><span id="MathJax-Span-492" class="mi">i</span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-493" class="mo">)</span></span></span><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation">p(zi=k|xi)</span></span>, where k = {0,1}For k=0, we get:

Similarly, for k=0, we get:

<span id="MathJax-Element-27-Frame" class="MathJax" style="box-sizing: border-box; display: inline-table; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: normal; font-size: 14px; text-indent: 2.1.3 M-Step: Computing the updated value of <span id="MathJax-Element-29-Frame" class="MathJax" style="box-sizing: border-box; display: inline-table; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: normal; font-size: 14px; text-indent: 0px; text-align: left; text-transform: none; letter-spacing: normal; word-spacing: normal; overflow-wrap: normal; white-space: nowrap; float: none; direction: ltr; max-width: none; max-height: none; min-width: 0px; min-height: 0px; border: 0px; padding: 0px; margin: 0px; position: relative;" tabindex="0" role="presentation" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mi>&amp;#x03BC;</mi></math>"><span id="MathJax-Span-698" class="math"><span id="MathJax-Span-699" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-700" class="mi">μ</span></span></span><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation">μ</span></span>To find the updated value of <span id="MathJax-Element-30-Frame" class="MathJax" style="box-sizing: border-box; display: inline-table; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: normal; font-size: 14px; text-indent: 0px; text-align: left; text-transform: none; letter-spacing: normal; word-spacing: normal; overflow-wrap: normal; white-space: nowrap; float: none; direction: ltr; max-width: none; max-height: none; min-width: 0px; min-height: 0px; border: 0px; padding: 0px; margin: 0px; position: relative;" tabindex="0" role="presentation" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mi>&amp;#x03BC;</mi></math>"><span id="MathJax-Span-701" class="math"><span id="MathJax-Span-702" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-703" class="mi">μ</span></span></span><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation">μ</span></span>, we need to solve the optimization problem:

To solve this optimization problem, we will find its derivative and equate it to 0.

Representing <span id="MathJax-Element-32-Frame" class="MathJax" style="box-sizing: border-box; display: inline-table; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: normal; font-size: 14px; text-indent: 0px; text-align: left; text-transform: none; letter-spacing: normal; word-spacing: normal; overflow-wrap: normal; white-space: nowrap; float: none; direction: ltr; max-width: none; max-height: none; min-width: 0px; <h3 id="2.2-EM-Algorithm-in-ABO-Blood-Groups-[10-pts]">2.2 EM Algorithm in ABO Blood Groups [10 pts]</h3>

In the ABO blood group system, each individual has a phenotype and a genotype as shown below. The genotype is made of underlying alleles (A, B, O).

In a research experiment, scientists wanted to model the distribution of the genotypes of the population. They collected the phenotype information from the participants as this could be directly observed from the individual’s blood group. The scientists, however want to use this data to model the underlying genotype information. In order to help them obtain an understanding, you suggest using the EM algorithm to find out the genotype distribution.

You know that the probability of that an allele is present in an individual is independent of the probability of any other allele, i.e, <span id="MathJax-Element-58-Frame" class="MathJax" style="box-sizing: border-box; display: inline-table; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: normal; font-size: 14px; text-indent: 0px; text-align: left; text-transform: none; letter-spacing: normal; word-spacing: normal; overflow-wrap: normal; white-space: nowrap; float: none; direction: ltr; max-width: none; max-height: none; min-width: 0px; min-height: 0px; border: 0px; padding: 0px; margin: 0px; position: relative;" tabindex="0" role="presentation" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mi>P</mi><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot;>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mi>O</mi><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot;>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>P</mi><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot;>(</mo><mi>O</mi><mi>A</mi><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot;>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>P</mi><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot;>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot;>)</mo><mo>&amp;#x2217;</mo><mi>P</mi><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot;>(</mo><mi>O</mi><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot;>)</mo></math>"><span id="MathJax-Span-1809" class="math"><span id="MathJax-Span-1810" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-1811" class="mi">P</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1812" class="mo">(</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1813" class="mi">A</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1814" class="mi">O</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1815" class="mo">)</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1816" class="mo">=</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1817" class="mi">P</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1818" class="mo">(</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1819" class="mi">O</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1820" class="mi">A</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1821" class="mo">)</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1822" class="mo">=</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1823" class="mi">P</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1824" class="mo">(</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1825" class="mi">A</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1826" class="mo">)</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1827" class="mo">∗</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1828" class="mi">P</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1829" class="mo">(</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1830" class="mi">O</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1831" class="mo">)</span></span></span><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation">P(AO)=P(OA)=P(A)∗P(O)</span></span> and so on. Also note that the genotype pairs: (AO, OA) and (BO, OB) are identical and can be treated as AO, BO respectively. You also know that the alleles follow a multinomial distribution.

Let <span id="MathJax-Element-60-Frame" class="MathJax" style="box-sizing: border-box; display: inline-table; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: normal; font-size: 14px; text-indent: 0px; text-align: left; text-transform: none; letter-spacing: normal; word-spacing: normal; overflow-wrap: normal; white-space: nowrap; float: none; direction: ltr; max-width: none; max-height: none; min-width: 0px; min-height: 0px; border: 0px; padding: 0px; margin: 0px; position: relative;" tabindex="0" role="presentation" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msub><mi>n</mi><mi>A</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mi>B</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mi>O</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mrow class=&quot;MJX-TeXAtom-ORD&quot;><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub></math>"><span id="MathJax-Span-1850" class="math"><span id="MathJax-Span-1851" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-1852" class="msubsup"><span id="MathJax-Span-1853" class="mi">n</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1854" class="mi">A</span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-1855" class="mo">,</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1856" class="msubsup"><span id="MathJax-Span-1857" class="mi">n</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1858" class="mi">B</span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-1859" class="mo">,</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1860" class="msubsup"><span id="MathJax-Span-1861" class="mi">n</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1862" class="mi">O</span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-1863" class="mo">,</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1864" class="msubsup"><span id="MathJax-Span-1865" class="mi">n</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1866" class="texatom"><span id="MathJax-Span-1867" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-1868" class="mi">A</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1869" class="mi">B</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation">nA,nB,nO,nAB</span></span> be the number of individuals with the phenotypes A, B, O and AB respectively. Let <span id="MathJax-Element-61-Frame" class="MathJax" style="box-sizing: border-box; display: inline-table; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: normal; font-size: 14px; text-indent: 0px; text-align: left; text-transform: none; letter-spacing: normal; word-spacing: normal; overflow-wrap: normal; white-space: nowrap; float: none; direction: ltr; max-width: none; xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msub><mi>n</mi><mrow class=&quot;MJX-TeXAtom-ORD&quot;><mi>A</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mrow class=&quot;MJX-TeXAtom-ORD&quot;><mi>A</mi><mi>O</mi></mrow></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mrow class=&quot;MJX-TeXAtom-ORD&quot;><mi>B</mi><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mrow class=&quot;MJX-TeXAtom-ORD&quot;><mi>B</mi><mi>O</mi></mrow></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mrow class=&quot;MJX-TeXAtom-ORD&quot;><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub></math>"><span id="MathJax-Span-1870" class="math"><span id="MathJax-Span-1871" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-1872" class="msubsup"><span id="MathJax-Span-1873" class="mi">n</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1874" class="texatom"><span id="MathJax-Span-1875" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-1876" class="mi">A</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1877" class="mi">A</span></span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-1878" class="mo">,</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1879" class="msubsup"><span id="MathJax-Span-1880" class="mi">n</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1881" class="texatom"><span id="MathJax-Span-1882" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-1883" class="mi">A</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1884" class="mi">O</span></span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-1885" class="mo">,</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1886" class="msubsup"><span id="MathJax-Span-1887" class="mi">n</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1888" class="texatom"><span id="MathJax-Span-1889" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-1890" class="mi">B</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1891" class="mi">B</span></span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-1892" class="mo">,</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1893" class="msubsup"><span id="MathJax-Span-1894" class="mi">n</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1895" class="texatom"><span id="MathJax-Span-1896" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-1897" class="mi">B</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1898" class="mi">O</span></span></span></span><span id="MathJax-Span-1899" class="mo">,</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1900" class="msubsup"><span id="MathJax-Span-1901" class="mi">n</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1902" class="texatom"><span id="MathJax-Span-1903" class="mrow"><span id="MathJax-Span-1904" class="mi">A</span><span id="MathJax-Span-1905" class="mi">B</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation">nAA,nAO,nBB,nBO,nAB</span></span> be the numbers of individuals with genotypes AA, AO, BB, BO and AB respectively. The satisfy the following conditions:
